Author: Bowers, Alex J.
Title: Analyzing the Longitudinal K-12 Grading Histories of Entire Cohorts of Students: Grades, Data Driven Decision Making, Dropping out and Hierarchical Cluster Analysis
Abstract Note: School personnel currently lack an effective method to pattern and visually interpret disaggregated achievement data collected on students as a means to help inform decision making. This study, through the examination of longitudinal K-12 teacher assigned grading histories for entire cohorts of students from a school district (n=188), demonstrates a novel application of hierarchical cluster analysis and pattern visualization in which all data points collected on every student in a cohort can be patterned, visualized and interpreted to aid in data driven decision making by teachers and administrators. Additionally, as a proof-of-concept study, overall schooling outcomes, such as student dropout or taking a college entrance exam, are identified from the data patterns and compared to past methods of dropout identification as one example of the usefulness of the method. Hierarchical cluster analysis correctly identified over 80% of the students who dropped out using the entire student grade history patterns from either K-12 or K-8. (Contains 5 figures.)
Short Title: Analyzing the Longitudinal K-12 Grading Histories of Entire Cohorts of Students
Notes:
Longitudnal k-12 teachers who assigned grading histories sample size of 188 were chosen as sample. Hierachical cluster analysis and pattern visualization were chosen as visualisation tools.
The results were that over 80% correctness of indentifying the students who dropped out using the entire student grade history patterns from either K-12 or K-8
The method here of using HCA retains the dis aggregated data for each student.
Automatic Tags: data; data analysis; Decision Making; Dropouts; Elementary School Students; Grades (Scholastic); Identification; MULTIVARIATE analysis; School Districts; Secondary School Students

Author: Grunspan, Daniel Z.; Wiggins, Benjamin L.; Goodreau, Steven M.
Title: Understanding Classrooms through Social Network Analysis: A Primer for Social Network Analysis in Education Research
Abstract Note: Social interactions between students are a major and underexplored part of undergraduate education. Understanding how learning relationships form in undergraduate classrooms, as well as the impacts these relationships have on learning outcomes, can inform educators in unique ways and improve educational reform. Social network analysis (SNA) provides the necessary tool kit for investigating questions involving relational data. We introduce basic concepts in SNA, along with methods for data collection, data processing, and data analysis, using a previously collected example study on an undergraduate biology classroom as a tutorial. We conduct descriptive analyses of the structure of the network of costudying relationships. We explore generative processes that create observed study networks between students and also test for an association between network position and success on exams. We also cover practical issues, such as the unique aspects of human subjects review for network studies. Our aims are to convince readers that using SNA in classroom environments allows rich and informative analyses to take place and to provide some initial tools for doing so, in the process inspiring future educational studies incorporating relational data.
Short Title: Understanding Classrooms through Social Network Analysis
Notes:
social networks analysis in diverse fields entails two broad classes of hypotheses:
  • those that seek to understand what influences the formation of relational ties in a given population
  • those that consider the influence
The structure of ties has on shaping outcomes, at either the individual level. for example GPA or socioeconomic status. The population level, e.g., graduation rates or retention in STEM] disciplines.
A network is nodes plus connections. its density  canbe defined as how many links are observed in a whole network divided by the total number of links that could exist if every actor were connected to every other actor.Network transitivity is a value representing the likelihood of student A being tied to C, given that A is tied to B and B is tied to C. Network centrality is the degree, centrality represents the total number of connections a node has.
Closeness centrality focuses on how close one node is to another on average, measured along geodesics
Between ness centrality focuses on whether actors serve as bridges in the shortest paths between two actors
Eigenvector centrality places importance on being connected to other well-connected individuals
Example study on an undergraduate biology classroom as a tutorial are used to analysesthe structure of the network of co-studying relationships, explored generative processes that create observed study networks between students and also tested for an association between network position and success on exams.

Author: Young, Jeffrey R.
Title: Why Students Should Own Their Educational Data
Publication Title: The Chronicle of Higher Education Blogs: Wired Campus
Notes:
Learning style theory comes from analyzing a population and trying to parse out different ways of learning over a population, but when you apply it to one individual it doesn’t hold. You can’t start with averages.
What we need to know about you is your contextualized profile of your performance and what kind of support you’ll need to be able to model your learner profile across contexts. Education is right now not so transparent and needs some transparency.

Author: Corbett, Albert T.; Anderson, John R.
Title: Knowledge tracing: Modeling the acquisition of procedural knowledge
Abstract Note: This paper describes an effort to model students' changing knowledge state during skill acquisition. Students in this research are learning to write short programs with the ACT Programming Tutor (APT). APT is constructed around a production rule cognitive model of programming knowledge, called theideal student model. This model allows the tutor to solve exercises along with the student and provide assistance as necessary. As the student works, the tutor also maintains an estimate of the probability that the student has learned each of the rules in the ideal model, in a process calledknowledge tracing. The tutor presents an individualized sequence of exercises to the student based on these probability estimates until the student has ‘mastered’ each rule. The programming tutor, cognitive model and learning and performance assumptions are described. A series of studies is reviewed that examine the empirical validity of knowledge tracing and has led to modifications in the process. Currently the model is quite successful in predicting test performance. Further modifications in the modeling process are discussed that may improve performance levels.
Notes: This article talks about knowledge tracing and ideal student model. The tutor presents an indivisualised sequence of exercises to the student based on probability estimates until the student has mastered each rule. Assumptions are described fro programming tutor, cognitive model, learning and performance models. Model is quite successful and further modifications are also discussed to improve the performance model.
Automatic Tags: Education (general); empirical validity; individual differences; intelligent tutoring systems; Learning; Management of Computing and Information Systems; mastery learning; Multimedia Information Systems; procedural knowledge; Psychology, general; student modeling; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction

Author: Siemens, George; Baker, Ryan S. J. d.
Title: Learning Analytics and Educational Data Mining: Towards Communication and Collaboration
Publication Title: Proceedings of the 2Nd International Conference on Learning Analytics and Knowledge
Abstract Note: Growing interest in data and analytics in education, teaching, and learning raises the priority for increased, high-quality research into the models, methods, technologies, and impact of analytics. Two research communities -- Educational Data Mining (EDM) and Learning Analytics and Knowledge (LAK) have developed separately to address this need. This paper argues for increased and formal communication and collaboration between these communities in order to share research, methods, and tools for data mining and analysis in the service of developing both LAK and EDM fields.
Short Title: Learning Analytics and Educational Data Mining
Notes:
EDM and LAK are both very new and emerging new fields where people are interested in analysing education, teaching and learning.

SoLAR was formed in 2011 to develop, advance and promote the research agenda in learning analytics.

"LAK and EDm share many attributes and have smilar goals and interests, they have distinct technological, ideological and methodological orientations."

Communities that can take part in LAK and EDM :

  • Schools
  • universities
  • Corporate learning organisations
  • Curriculum organisations

Society of LA Research defines LA as "the measurement, collection, analysis and reporting data about learners and their contexts, for purposes of understanding and optimising learning and the environments in which it occurs."

LAK and EDm both share the goal of improving education by improving assesment, how problems in education are understood, and how interventions are planned and selected. EDM and LAK have different roots yet they are interconnected and some researches in each can be placed in the other side as well.

differences between EDM and LAk are discussed.

The author also states that collaboration between the 2 can be great importance in research.
Automatic Tags: Collaboration; educational data mining; learning analytics and knowledge

Author: Baker, Ryan S. J. d; Corbett, Albert T.; Roll, Ido; Koedinger, Kenneth R.
Title: Developing a generalizable detector of when students game the system
Abstract Note: Some students, when working in interactive learning environments, attempt to “game the system”, attempting to succeed in the environment by exploiting properties of the system rather than by learning the material and trying to use that knowledge to answer correctly. In this paper, we present a system that can accurately detect whether a student is gaming the system, within a Cognitive Tutor mathematics curricula. Our detector also distinguishes between two distinct types of gaming which are associated with different learning outcomes. We explore this detector’s generalizability, and find that it transfers successfully to both new students and new tutor lessons.
Automatic Tags: Behavior detection; Cognitive tutors; Education (general); Gaming the system; Generalizable models; Interactive learning environments; Latent response models; Machine learning; Management of Computing and Information Systems; Multimedia Information Systems; student modeling; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction

Author: Clow, Doug
Title: Data wranglers: human interpreters to help close the feedback loop
Publication Title: Proceedings of the Fourth International Conference on Learning Analytics And Knowledge
Notes:
Data wranglers are a group of academics who analyse data about students learning and prepare actionable reports on the data based on the data.: to act as sense makers,facilitate action on feedback fro learner,making sense of the feedback and improving it. this is double looped learning.

4 main data sources they work on include : Survey feedback data from students, activity data at moodle, mode of delivery of the course data, aggregated completion, pass rate and demographic rate.

they also support delivery of learning design activities.

Role of data wrangler is to analyse data, increase the familiarity of academics with the learning analytics community. they present data from all sources to all users.he is the one component of quality assurance and quality enhancement.

Example when data wranglers work on when students use the moodle components most frequently, they found that the weeks when students were suppose to get graded or assessed for their performance they were more active and otherwise not so active. Factors like assessment, student's level of enjoyment and how the weeks were connected to direct experience were responsible for their behaviour

Aim of data wranglers is to improve the learning experience.

one of the largest issues was the data quality received.

Author: Kucirkova, Natalia; FitzGerald, Elizabeth
Title: Zuckerberg is ploughing billions into 'personalised learning' – why?
Abstract Note: Zuckerburg wants to plough billions into personalised learning, but his way may not be the right way.
Notes:
Zuckerberg discusses personalised learning in detail. He finds it most important. but there are 3 major flaws in his idea of personalised learning:

  1. the general content may not be delivered to students who wish to pursue personalised/specific learning.
  2. learner may not well know what method is well suited for him / her for learning and may choose the wrong one.
  3. children's preference often change and to predict content relevant to them may not be suitable.

Personalised learning could help in giving students ownership and relevance, with motivation.

Author: san Pedro, Maria Ofelia; Baker, Ryan; Bowers, Alex; Heffernan, Neil
Title: Predicting college enrollment from student interaction with an intelligent tutoring system in middle school
Notes:
This very interesting. to predict college enrollment from student interaction with intelligent tutoring system.

many factors such as financial resources, family background, career aspirations and academic ability are indicative of a career goal or students choice to attend college.

Here san pedro, Baker and Bowers worked together to predict college attendence using 3747 students data using ASSIST ment system in New England.

Knowledge affect and behaviour models were applied to the bulky data (man so many pointer and data points) to create feature that they used to predict college enrollment. BKT and Kappa were used while building the accurate model. Logistic regression model was developed. They were successful in detecting and distinguishing students who will attend college 68.6% of the time from those who will not. Boredom, confusion and carelessness were some other important factors that played a major role in predicting these results.

It was concluded that many factors like financial reasons, parental support, and school support, one's ability to engage were influential in predicting college enrollments.

Author: Greller, Wolfgang; Drachsler, Hendrik
Title: Translating Learning into Numbers: A Generic Framework for Learning Analytics
Abstract Note: ABSTRACT With the increase in available educational data, it is expected that Learning Analytics will become a powerful means to inform and support learners, teachers and their institutions in better understanding and predicting personal learning needs and performance. However, the processes and requirements behind the beneficial application of Learning and Knowledge Analytics as well as the consequences for learning and teaching are still far from being understood. In this paper, we explore the key dimensions of Learning Analytics (LA), the critical problem zones, and some potential dangers to the beneficial exploitation of educational data. We propose and discuss a generic design framework that can act as a useful guide for setting up Learning Analytics services in support of educational practice and learner guidance, in quality assurance, curriculum development, and in improving teacher effectiveness and efficiency. Furthermore, the presented article intends to inform about soft barriers and limitations of Learning Analytics. We identify the required skills and competences that make meaningful use of Learning Analytics data possible to overcome gaps in interpretation literacy among educational stakeholders. We also discuss privacy and ethical issues and suggest ways in which these issues can be addressed through policy guidelines and best practice examples.
Notes:
Dimensions to analyze learning:

Stakeholders include data subjects or learners, data clients like tutor and discussion moderator
Objectives can be
  • to analyse student interactions in a forum discussion 
  • identify network connections between students
  • identify isolated students to bring them back into the discussion
the main opportunities for LA as a domain are discussed
Pedagogic theory, Technology, Presentation
External limitations were discussed like: Conventions; Norms; Time scale
Internal limitations: Required competences like Interpretation: explain the result, Critical thinking: what to use

Author: Kay, Judy; Maisonneuve, Nicolas; Yacef, Kalina; Reimann, Peter
Title: The Big Five and Visualisations of Team Work Activity
Abstract Note: We have created a set of novel visualisations of group activity: they mirror activity of individuals and their interactions, based upon readily available authentic data. We evaluated these visualisations in the context of a semester long software development project course. We give a theoretical analysis of the design of our visualizations using the framework from the “Big 5” theory of team work as well as a qualitative study of the visualisations and the students’ reflective reports. We conclude that these visualisations provide a powerful and valuable mirroring role with potential, when well used, to help groups learn to improve their effectiveness.
Notes:
Computer-supported collaborative learning (CSCL)

“Big Five” components of teamwork:

  1. team leadership
  2. mutual performance monitoring
  3. backup behavior
  4. adaptability
  5. team orientation

Visualizations like

  • activity radar (presenting everyone's level of participation)
  • interaction network (SNS)
  • wattle tree (the size of flowers presenting the "size" of contribution along timethe leaves showing ticket-related actions)

Visualisation externalises the long-term activity of groups. The Wattle Tree has proven particularly useful because it gives the right mix of detail and high level summary over a long period.
Automatic Tags: Artificial Intelligence (incl. Robotics); Computers and Education; Information Systems Applications (incl. Internet); Multimedia Information Systems; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction
Editor: Ikeda, Mitsuru; Ashley, Kevin D.; Chan, Tak-Wai

Author: Konstan, Joseph A.; Walker, J. D.; Brooks, D. Christopher; Brown, Keith; Ekstrand, Michael D.
Title: Teaching Recommender Systems at Large Scale: Evaluation and Lessons Learned from a Hybrid MOOC
Short Title: Teaching Recommender Systems at Large Scale
Notes:
Hybrid MOOC

Coursera

they tracked students through courses including separating out students enrolled for credit from those enrolled only for the free, open courses. Student course completion was hard to predict, but the main factor they considered was the intent to complete.

to this my question is if students want to complete the course is fine, but then conditions may come across where he certainly cannot. then what.

They also examined the students who chose concepts only track and those who chose the programmed track with assignments.

their model showed that knowledge,experience, and strong intentions influenced both measure of completion. The higher a student scored on the knowledge pre test, the greater the number of MOOCs she had taken on the past, and the stronger her intention to complete the course, the more likely was it that she would complete both writing assignments and exam questions.

they also found that the even if the students showed a strong intend to complete the course, the results were not that strong for that and were not correlated. they also conducted a survey where they asked question if the course was helpful, 95% responded in agreement. wile in a question they asked about the length of the course 60% students responded that 14 weeks was very long for a online course.

Final result was that predicting the completion is really hard, factors can contribute towards it but it may be different for different people.
Automatic Tags: learning assessment; Massively Online Open Course (MOOC)

Author: Desmarais, Michel C.; Naceur, Rhouma
Title: A Matrix Factorization Method for Mapping Items to Skills and for Enhancing Expert-Based Q-Matrices
Abstract Note: Uncovering the right skills behind question items is a difficult task. It requires a thorough understanding of the subject matter and of the cognitive factors that determine student performance. The skills definition, and the mapping of item to skills, require the involvement of experts. We investigate means to assist experts for this task by using a data driven, matrix factorization approach. The two mappings of items to skills, the expert on one side and the matrix factorization on the other, are compared in terms of discrepancies, and in terms of their performance when used in a linear model of skills assessment and item outcome prediction. Visual analysis shows a relatively similar pattern between the expert and the factorized mappings, although differences arise. The prediction comparison shows the factorization approach performs slightly better than the original expert Q-matrix, giving supporting evidence to the belief that the factorization mapping is valid. Implications for the use of the factorization to design better item to skills mapping are discussed.
Automatic Tags: alternating least squares matrix factorization; Artificial Intelligence (incl. Robotics); Cognitive modeling; Computers and Education; Educational Technology; Information Systems Applications (incl. Internet); latent skills; Pedagogic Psychology; skills assessment; Student models; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction
Editor: Lane, H. Chad; Yacef, Kalina; Mostow, Jack; Pavlik, Philip

Author: Matsuda, Noboru; Furukawa, Tadanobu; Bier, Norman; Faloutsos, Christos
Title: Machine Beats Experts: Automatic Discovery of Skill Models for Data-Driven Online Course Refinement
Abstract Note: How can we automatically determine which skills must be mastered for the successful completion of an online course? Large-scale online courses (e.g., MOOCs) often contain a broad range of contents frequently intended to be a semester's worth of materials; this breadth often makes it difficult to articulate an accurate set of skills and knowledge (i.e., a skill model, or the QMatrix). We have developed an innovative method to discover skill models from the data of online courses. Our method assumes that online courses have a pre-defined skill map for which skills are associated with formative assessment items embedded throughout the online course. Our method carefully exploits correlations between various parts of student performance, as well as in the text of assessment items, to build a superior statistical model that even outperforms human experts. To evaluate our method, we compare our method with existing methods (LFA) and human engineered skill models on three Open Learning Initiative (OLI) courses at Carnegie Mellon University. The results show that (1) our method outperforms human-engineered skill models, (2) skill models discovered by our method are interpretable, and (3) our method is remarkably faster than existing methods. These results suggest that our method provides a significant contribution to the evidence-based, iterative refinement of online courses with a promising scalability. [For complete proceedings, see ED560503.]
Notes:
MOOCs often contain a large amount of content to be mastered that is worth a semester worth of a course. Here Matsuda et al. worked and developed an innovative method to discover skills from data of online courses. The method assumes that these courses have a pr defined skill map for which skill are associated with formative assessment items embeded throughout the online course. Students performance and assessment are used to build a superior statistical model that can outperform human experts. They used open learning initiative courses and existing methods at Carnegie Mellon University.build a skill model for online courses.

The results show that

  1. their method outperforms human-engineered skill models.
  2. Skill models are interpretable which were discovered in this process/research
  3. It is a faster method than existing methods.
  4. Their method provides a significant contribution to the evidence-based, iterative refinement of online courses with a promising scalability.
  5. eEPIPHANY isan efficient, practical, and quick method to automatically discover skill models from online course data without human interaction.
Automatic Tags: Automation; Comparative Analysis; Correlation; data; Formative Evaluation; models; Online Courses; Skills

Author: Cortez, Paulo; Silva, Alice Maria Gonçalves
Title: Using data mining to predict secondary school student performance
Publication Title: Proceedings of 5th Annual Future Business Technology Conference
Abstract Note: Although the educational level of the Portuguese population has improved in the last decades, the statistics keep Portugal at Europe’s tail end due to its high student failure rates. In particular, lack of success in the core classes of Mathematics and the Portuguese language is extremely serious. On the other hand, the fields of Business Intelligence (BI)/Data Mining (DM), which aim at extracting high-level knowledge from raw data, offer interesting automated tools that can aid the education domain. The present work intends to approach student achievement in secondary education using BI/DM techniques. Recent real-world data (e.g. student grades, demographic, social and school related features) was collected by using school reports and questionnaires. The two core classes (i.e. Mathematics and Portuguese) were modeled under binary/five-level classification and regression tasks. Also, four DM models (i.e. Decision Trees, Random Forest, Neural Networks and Support Vector Machines) and three input selections (e.g. with and without previous grades) were tested. The results show that a good predictive accuracy can be achieved, provided that the first and/or second school period grades are available. Although student achievement is highly influenced by past evaluations, an explanatory analysis has shown that there are also other relevant features (e.g. number of absences, parent’s job and education, alcohol consumption). As a direct outcome of this research, more efficient student prediction tools can be be developed, improving the quality of education and enhancing school resource management.
Notes:
he fields of Business Intelligence (BI)/Data Mining (DM) aim at extracting high-level knowledge from raw data.

They offer interesting automated tools that can aid the education domain as well.

This work in the article intends to approach student achievement in secondary education using BI/DM techniques. Real-world data like student grades, demographic, social and school related features were collected by using school reports and questionnaire. The two core classes maths and portuguese were modeled under binary/five-level classification and regression tasks.

Decision trees, random forest, neural networks and support vector machines were tested in this research.The results show that a good predictive accuracy can be achieved, provided that the first and/or second school period grades are available. it also showed that student achievement is highly influenced by past evaluations. Other relevant features e.g. number of absences, parent’s job and education, alcohol consumption also affect the grades. This research canbe used a base ground to get ideas to improve education in classrooms. As a direct outcome of this research, more efficient student prediction tools can be be developed, improving the quality of education and enhancing school resource management.

In this paper, we present a system that can accurately detect whether a student is gaming the system, within a Cognitive Tutor mathematics curricula. Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 6.1 Learning Curves
Notes:
video 1
visualisation
learning curves

Displaying information in a meaningful information

Visualisation should
- show the data
- induce the viewerto think about the substance
- avoid distorting what the data have to say
- make large datasets coherent
- encourage the eye to compare different pieces of data
- reveal the data at several levels

it is a big area

some visualisations important with edu data:
Learning curves:
Classical learning curve- the student is practicing the same skill in approximately the same fashion


;

Visualization

Scatter plots

Heat maps

Parameter space maps

You may get giant blobs or the data may be granular. In case of granular data you get single points hiding lots of data points like one point may correspond to 5 points and the other may correspond to 500,000 points just because they were lying on the same point.

Possible solution can be to display size difference in those points: 500,000 versus 5 points may be hard to display. But if the data is somewhat granular, data points may get covered.

Heat maps : These can be used to shoe the density of the data in specific regions. High density can be red ones and lowest density density can be blue

These can do better with large scale data

Whats important is to get the right box size and its ok to experiment a little.

It can be not just a substitute for scatter plots but can be used for intensity as well as density.

Parameter space maps

  • Important special case of heat maps – used to look at the goodness of various parameters, particularly for bkt.
  • Average graphs
  • Is another alternative to scatter plots
  • y axis shows the average value (+- 1 SD) for each value of the x axis
  • Bottom line  - lots of alternatives to scatter plots
  • Make this visualization more useful for big data

the video has a lot of different plots that are worth looking at.

;

Visualization

State space diagrams

  • Visualization of all the states that the learning system can have during a problem
  • State = complete characterization of the situation.
  • These diagrams are also referred to as student learning pathways or interaction networks

State space diagrams in refraction:

This can show single student trajectories – differentiate between successful and non successful students

If the student goes back and forth endlessly between a small number of states, it may be because of not understanding concepts

It can also be used to show all paths and for more complex systems  

In this the one above is start state

The more thicker lines correspond to more no. of students corresponding to that line and the green dots sho the students who were successful.

Uses of this plot

  • To study specific student trajectory
  • To see which paths end up being productive
  • To see which parts are rare despite of being productive
  • Make recommendations or hints to students based on their paths

plots in the video give meaning to all this, please consider them. they have also been saved separately.

Assumptions: We have some way to measure student performance over time - speed or accuracy

Characteristic problem, power law of learning - performance both speed and accuracy improves with a power function, may be a power function instead of exponential function'

Radical improvement at first which slows over time towards as asymptote, passing the asymptote usually involves developing entirely new strategy

power law of learning:

  • simple domains - passing correct button on stimulus
  • complex problem solving domains - maths, programming
  • real world domains - cigar making is factories

real world are rarely smooth. like normal learning, cigar eg.

USES:

  • to understand how and whether a skill is being learned across students - data shop is good for doing this

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 7.1 Clustering
Notes:
CLUSTERING

A type of Structure Discovery diagram

  • You have a large number of data points
  • You want to find what structure there is among the data points
  • You don’t know anything a priori about the structure
  • Clustering tries to find data points that group together

Examples

  • Lets say our data has two variables
  • Probability the students knows the skill from bkt (pkniw)
  • Unitized time
  • Note clustering works for and is effective in large feature spaces
  • First decide how many clusters you want
  • Pick the starting values for the centeroids of the clusters
  • Usually chosen randomly
  • Sometimes there are good reasons to start with specific initial values
  • out liers can make extra clusters
  • K means clustering algorithm
  • pick cluster and try solutions.
  • changing the centroids can change the number of clusters

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 7.2 Validation and Selection
Notes:
K means clustering

how do we choose the value of k

  • take each point p, find the centroid of p's cluster c
  • find thedistance d from c to p
  • square d to get d'
  • sum all d' to get the distortion - mean squared deviation
  • you can use euclidiean distance
  • more clusters almost always leads to smaller distortion
  • cross validation may not be really helpful
  • 14 ill chosen centroids is worse than 2 well chosen centroids.
  • you can use bayeseien validation criterion

try several values of k : chose the l that has best bic or aic

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 7.6 Knowledge Inference: Q-Matrix Knowledge Structure
Short Title: Big Data in Education 7.6 Knowledge Inference
Notes:
Q matrix/Knowledge component model(kc)/ skill item mapping:

  • its a table where rows are items and columns are skills.
  • every item involves a skill.

how do we do skill item mapping:

  • automatic model discovery
  • hand development and refinement
  • hybrid approaches

Automatic model discovery

  • learn the mapping between items and skills solely from data
  • how many skills should we use
  • this is determined emperically
  • try 1  skill
  • try 2 skill model
  • if 2 skill model does better than 1 skill then try 3 skills and so on untill nothing gets better
  • this avoids local minima
  • if an item has general relevant skill
  • you want all the items right

3 strategies for Q matrix refinement

  • try to smooth learning curves
  • look for skills with no appearant learning
  • look for problems wit unexpected error rates

you can use data shop or excel etc.

Learning curve shows the relationship between amount of practices and performance

plc data shop learning tool - if you work with gepmetry curve - nothing specific can be seen or it is a mess or the curve is not smooth. but if you break it into 12 skills the curves may be smooth depicting the various skills. if it doesnt you can improve the model

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 1.1 Introduction
Notes:
Big data in education

methods for exploring big data in education - also called educational data mining or learning analytics.

  • these 2 communities have a joint goal of exploring the big data now available on learners and learning
  • to promote:
  1. new scientific discoveries and to advance learning scince
  2. better assessment of learners along multiple dimensions  - social, cognitive, emotional, meta-cognitive etc. or individual, group, institutional etc.
  3. for better and real time support for learners

Educational data is big but not google big

Types of edm/la methods

  • prediction

- classification

- regression

- latent knowledge estimation

  • structure discovery

- clustering

- factor analysis

- domain structure discovery

- network analyisis

  • relationship mining

- association rule mining

- co relation mining

- sequential pattern mining

casual data mining

  • distillation of data for human judgement
  • discovery with models

PREDICTION

  • develop a model which can infer a single aspect of the data, i.e. the predicted variable, for some combination of other aspects of the data that are predictor variables. which students are off task or which students will fail the class.
  • Discover the structure or pattern in the data
  • no specific target or predictor variable
  • discover the relationship between variables in a data set with many variables
  • this can be discovered with models - like pre existing models developed with edm prediction methods or clustering or knowledge component. or apply to data and use as a component in another analysis.

PSLC Data Shop is a very good public educational software interaction data.

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 1.3 Classifiers, Part 1
Notes:
Classifiers

Prediction :

  • Develop a model which can infer a single aspect of the data
  • sometimes use to predict future
  • sometimes used to make inferences about present

classification :

  • something you want to predict (the label)
  • the thing we want to predict is categorical - eg. will drop out or not. will enroll in mooc a or not or b or not.  these can be expressed as 0,1.

these labels come from

  • in software performance
  • school records
  • test data
  • survey data
  • field observations or video coding
  • text replays

classification

  • associated with features which may predict the label
  • domain specific algorithms can be done
  • step regression, logistic regression, j48/c4.5 decision trees
  • jrip decision rules
  • k instance based classifiers

Step regression is not step wise regression, it selects parameters, assigns a weight to each parameter, computers a numerical value. not prefered by staticians

Logistic regression : given a specific set of values of predictor variables, it finds out the frequency / odds of a specific value of the dependent variable.video talks better about all these methods

method of generating rules from decision trees is there

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 2.2 Diagnostic Metrics Part 1
Notes:
Diagnostic metrics

Different methods and measures - Metrics for classifiers

Accuracy is one of the easiest measures of model goodness. also known as agreement. when measuring inter rater reliability it is no. of agreements/ total no. of codes or assessments. it is good if 92% is the case but what if the real case is that 92% of the students pass kindergarten but my detector always shows PASS, regardless of the case. hence, despite my detector being 92% accurate, it is completely useless and there is no information at all.

Kappa = (agreement - expected agreement) / (1- expected agreement)

eg. of calculation on video

Interpreting kappa

  • kappa = 0 - agreement is at chance
  • kappa = 1 - agreement is perfect
  • kappa = -1 - agreement is perfect inverse
  • kappa > 1 - you messed up somewhere.. hahaha :D
  • kappa < 0 - model is worse than chance
  • in case of cross validation u see it
  • in this one model goes to opposite direction
  • 0 < kappa < 1 - its fine but you should be looking for numbers near 1

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 2.3  Diagnostic Metrics Part 2
Notes:
Diagnostic Metrics

Reciever Operator characteristic curve - ROC - predicting something which has 2 values- correct or incorrect or gaming n not gaming. it says probability. have a threshold.

4 possibilities -

  1. true positive
  2. true negative
  3. false positive
  4. false negative

good model, chance model, poor model, bad model. many examples in video.

z test can be done for comparing any 2 models

there are complications as well in calculating these values.

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 2.4 Diagnostic Metrics: Correlation
Short Title: Big Data in Education 2.4 Diagnostic Metrics
Notes:
Metrics for regressors

  • linear correlation - more in prof. decarlo notes
  • mad - mean absolute deviation - average of absolute value (actual value - predicted value. it tells the average amount to which the predictionsdeviate from the actual values
  • rmse - root mean squared error - it can be interpreted the same way but penalizeslarge deviations more than small deviations.
  • low rmse/mad is good
  • high corerelation is good
  • corelation is more important

 

  • information criteria
  • Bayesian information criteria - makestrade off between goodness of fit and flexibility of fit
  • >0 bad
  • <0 better
  • Akaike's information criteria - statistically equivalent to leave out - one cross validation

aic or bic which should we use

  •  try to understand the model deeply in multiple dimensions

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 2.5 Cross-Validation and Over-Fitting
Notes:
Cross validation and over fitting

Over fitting - is your model fitting to the noise as well as the signal. in other words is model any good or not. no noise is great. good examples in video.

to reduce over fitting - we can use simpler models with fewer variables, less complex variables. 

to assess generalizability we need to assess if our model can fit to other contexts as well.

we divide the datset into 2 parts - one to standardise the detector and the other one to test the generalizability of the detector. this is all to cross validate what we are trying to do.

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 4.2 Bayesian Knowledge Tracing
Notes:
Knowledge inference - bayesian knowledge trading - bkt

  • measuring how well a student knows a specific skill / knowledge component at a specific time.
  • based on their pst history of performance with that skill / kc
  • to measure a specific skill or knowledge component

typical use of bkt - assess a student's knowledge of skill/kc x. - based on a sequence of items that are dichotomously scored

Title: Passing the Privacy Test as Student Data Laws Take Effect (EdSurge News)
Abstract Note: On January 1, 2016, “ 	SOPIPA”—the recently passed California student data privacy law that defines how edtech companies can use student data became effective. About 25 other states have passed similar laws that are already in effect, or will become effective.  At the same time, more than 200 sc
Notes:
SOPIPA 
California student data privacy law included:
  • Edtech companies' restricted use of students' data
  • they supported parental access to data
  • obligation were put to delete data when required
  • Public schools' have restricted requirement for students of sharing data and mandatory responsibility of informing students' and their parents of data-privacy-related issues
  • Students' data for educational purposes are strictly forbidden to be used for commercial use.
Anonymized information, can be analyzed and shared, while there is still some restrictions, e.g. SOPIPA limits the use of them to purposes like product improvement, but not for advertising.
But what's not included is students' data generated on general market services
